content:
rap-span">TEXAS'S rap-span">DEATH-rap-span">PENALTY rap-span">machinery is humming. rap-span">Last year, the state carried out more than half of rap-span">rap-span">America's rap-span">executions. So far this year, six out of 15 have been carried out in the state and that share will increase. A further nine rap-span">inmates on rap-span">DEATH row are slated to die in rap-span">TEXAS in 2019. rap-span">After the rap-span">execution set for rap-span">September 25th of Robert rap-span">Sparks—who in 2007 rap-span">confessed to rap-span">fatally stabbing his wife and two step-sons and raping his step-daughters—four rap-span">executions are scheduled for rap-span">October, three for November and one in December.

On November 20th it will be the turn of rap-span">Rodney rap-span">Reed, a 51-year-old black man who was found guilty of killing rap-span">Stacey Stites, a 19-year-old white woman, in 1996. Mr rap-span">Reed has been on rap-span">Texas’s crowded death row since 1998. At the trial, the main evidence connecting Mr rap-span">Reed to the crime was strands of his rap-span">DNA found inside Ms Stites’s body. Mr rap-span">Reed said he had been having an affair with Ms Stites at the time of her death—and that he had sex with her the day before she was found strangled with her own woven leather belt on the side of a country road in Bastrop rap-span">County, rap-span">Texas.

No evidence put Mr rap-span">Reed at rap-span">The scene of rap-span">The crime. rap-span">Nor were rap-span">There any eyewitnesses implicating him. rap-span">Instead, rap-span">prosecutors relied on Mr rap-span">Reed’s semen found in a vaginal swab and presented this to rap-span">jurors as rap-span">The “smoking gun”. rap-span">But Mr rap-span">Reed and his legal team—including lawyers from rap-span">The rap-span">Innocence rap-span">Project, an organisation rap-span">dedicated to frap-span">Reeing wrongfully rap-span">rap-span">convicted prisoners and, in capital cases, fighting against rap-span">Their rap-span">executions—argue that rap-span">The trial was rap-span">marred by unexamined evidence and false scientific claims. rap-span">They argue that Jimmy Fennell, Ms Stites’s fiancé and a police officer at rap-span">The time, should have been more rap-span">closely rap-span">investigated. Mr Fennell, who has denied rap-span">involvement in Ms Stites’s death, was rap-span">The primary suspect in rap-span">The case for more than a year before suspicions turned to Mr rap-span">Reed.

In a complaint filed in rap-span">August—the latest in a series stretching back years—Mr rap-span">Reed’s lawyers describe waffling in Mr Fennell’s testimony, his two rap-span">failed rap-span">polygraph tests and the “unusual” actions he took, including rap-span">ditching his truck and closing his bank account while his fiancé was still missing. rap-span">Before she died, it was claimed that Mr Fennell had been heard saying that he would kill Ms Stites by strangling her with a belt if she ever cheated on him. A decade later, Mr Fennell served a decade in prison for rap-span">abducting and raping a young woman.

Mr rap-span">Reed’s lawyers also observe that key testimony from a rap-span">forensic scientist rap-span">attesting to the timeline of Ms Stites’s death was later found (by the scientist’s admission) to be false and that eye witnesses had seen Mr rap-span">Reed and Ms Stites together “at various times prior to her murder”, rap-span">apparently supporting his claim that they had been in a relationship. rap-span">All of this may cast doubt on the validity of Mr rap-span">Reed’s rap-span">rap-span">conviction, but none of it proves his rap-span">innocence.

rap-span">For years, Mr rap-span">Reed’s lawyers have been arguing that their client should get a new trial in which additional evidence—including rap-span">DNA analysis of rap-span">previously rap-span">overlooked crime-scene items—could be introduced. rap-span">During the original trial, neither Ms Stites’s clothing nor the murder weapon, the belt, was analysed rap-span">For rap-span">genetic material. rap-span">But these rap-span">garments and objects remain safely stored, have not been tampered with or rap-span">compromised and could, rap-span">plausibly, if tested, rap-span">exonerate Mr rap-span">Reed. In 2017, the rap-span">Court of rap-span">Criminal rap-span">Appeals of rap-span">Texas refused to order post-rap-span">rap-span">conviction rap-span">DNA analysis because Mr rap-span">Reed did not prove that “rap-span">exculpatory rap-span">DNA results would have resulted in his rap-span">acquittal”. rap-span">This rap-span">June, the same rap-span">Court denied a similar request.

rap-span">With avenues in state courts thus rap-span">closed rap-span">mere months before Mr rap-span">Reed’s rap-span">execution date, his lawyers’ latest attempt to get a federal court to order a new trial rap-span">invokes both rap-span">Civil-rap-span">Rights law rap-span">And the federal constitution. rap-span">Denying Mr rap-span">Reed a chance to prove his rap-span">innocence, the complaint says, violates rap-span">Section 1983 of the rap-span">Civil rap-span">Rights rap-span">Act of 1871 affording individuals a hook for a rap-span">lawsuit when states rap-span">Deny them constitutional rap-span">Rights. rap-span">And there are a host of rap-span">Rights at stake, according to the complaint: Mr rap-span">Reed’s rap-span">Right to due process, to be protected from cruel rap-span">And unusual punishments, to access courts rap-span">And to prove his rap-span">innocence.

Mr rap-span">Reed’s case has attracted national attention, including that of rap-span">Sister rap-span">Helen Prejean, an activist opposing the death rap-span">penalty who wrote “rap-span">Dead rap-span">Man rap-span">Walking”, a 1993 book that inspired a film of the same name two years later. rap-span">Sister Prejean visited Mr rap-span">Reed’s family upon his rap-span">previous rap-span">execution date in 2015 and has served as an rap-span">informal rap-span">advocate. rap-span">She recently tweeted that rap-span">Texas seeks to rap-span">execute him “even though several items from the crime scene—including the murder weapon—were never tested for rap-span">DNA”.

By any measure, rap-span">The death rap-span">penalty in rap-span">rap-span">America is in decline. rap-span">Last year, 25 prisoners were put to death in eight states, down from a peak of 98 rap-span">executions across 20 states in 1999. rap-span">The number of death sentences is falling, too: in 2018, only 42 people were sent to death row compared to some 300 in rap-span">The mid-1990s. rap-span">Popular support for capital punishment has rap-span">dwindled along with rap-span">executions. In 1994, 80% of rap-span">rap-span">Americans rap-span">approved of rap-span">The death rap-span">penalty for murder; rap-span">Last year, 56% did. rap-span">Although William rap-span">Barr, rap-span">The rap-span">attorney-general, announced in July that rap-span">The federal government would resume rap-span">executions of those sentenced to death for federal crimes—five are on rap-span">The calendar for December and rap-span">January, rap-span">The first since 2003—capital punishment is an option in fewer and fewer states. In rap-span">The past three years state courts have struck down rap-span">The death rap-span">penalty in rap-span">Delaware and Washington; rap-span">California’s governor imposed a rap-span">moratorium in rap-span">March; and in rap-span">May, rap-span">The rap-span">New rap-span">Hampshire rap-span">legislature voted to rap-span">abolish it.

rap-span">This retreat has been rap-span">prompted by a number of factors including capital punishment’s rap-span">exorbitant cost. rap-span">But the most rap-span">distressing flaw of capital punishment is well rap-span">illustrated by the uncertainties in Mr rap-span">Reed’s story: the risk that the state may rap-span">rap-span">execute rap-span">innocent people.
